{{Infobox animanga character | name = Roy Mustang | series = [[Fullmetal Alchemist]] | image = [[File:Mustangteam.jpg|185px]] | caption = Roy Mustang by Hiromu Arakawa | first = ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' manga chapter 4 | creator = [[Hiromu Arakawa]] | voiced by = '''Japanese'''
[[Toru Okawa]] (1st series)
[[Shin-ichiro Miki]] (2nd series)
'''English'''
[[Travis Willingham]]{{cite episode|title=Mother|airdate=November 20, 2004|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} | oaux1 name = Portrayed by | oaux1 = [[Dean Fujioka]] | alias = Flame Alchemist }} {{nihongo|'''Roy Mustang'''|ロイ・マスタング|Roi Masutangu}} is a [[fictional character]] from the ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist]]'' [[manga]] series and its adaptations created by [[Hiromu Arakawa]]. In the series, Mustang is a State Alchemist of Amestris' [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#State Military|State Military]], as well as the superior of the series' [[protagonist]], [[Edward Elric]]. Mustang holds the title of {{nihongo|"Flame Alchemist"|焔の錬金術師|Honō no Renkinjutsushi}} for his ability to create fire with alchemy, and he ambitiously strives to become the next leader of Amestris. Despite his ambition, as the series continues, Mustang decides to overthrow the State Military after his best friend, [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Maes Hughes|Maes Hughes]], is killed by the [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Homunculi|homunculi]], who are controlling the Military. Besides his appearances in the manga and the anime, Mustang has also been featured in other media for the series, such as Makoto Inoue's [[light novel]]s, the [[original video animation]]s and the ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' [[video game]]s. Since his introduction in the manga series, Mustang has been well received by readers, appearing second in each popularity poll for the series. His character has also received praise in various outside media, with many of them focusing on his character and development in both manga and anime. ==Appearances== Roy Mustang is introduced in ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' as a 29-year-old State Alchemist working for Amestris' State Military and as [[Edward Elric]]'s superior. Outwardly arrogant and playfully manipulative, Mustang is intelligent and adaptable.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 1|chapter=Chapter 4|year=2005|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-59116-920-8}} At the beginning of the series, he appears as a ruthless careerist and a womanizer. However, he is known to bear strong feelings towards [[Riza Hawkeye]], although he seldom shows it. He is also eventually shown to be a rather paternal commander who greatly cares for the emotional and physical well-being of his men, which earns him the fierce loyalty of his subordinates.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 6|chapter=Chapter 24|year=2006|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-0319-6}} This paternal nature stems from his experience in the Ishbal Civil War, where he was forced to kill using his flame alchemy, despite having learned it to help people. Angered with how he was used in the war, Mustang resolved to become the country's next leader.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 14|chapter=Chapter 59|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-1380-5}} An extremely powerful alchemist in his own right, Mustang wears gloves made from "ignition cloth" with transmutation circles that create sparks or flames when he rubs his fingers together. By adjusting the oxygen densities in the surrounding atmosphere through alchemy, he can create flames anywhere in the surrounding area at will and manipulate them as he desires with "pinpoint accuracy".{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 2|chapter=Chapter 5|year=2005|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-59116-923-9}} While it is often commented that Mustang is unable to produce fire with his gloves wet,{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 2|chapter=Chapter 7|year=2005|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-59116-923-9}} he can as long as he has some way to call up flame.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 10|chapter=Chapter 38|year=2006|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-0461-2}} Following the death of his best friend, [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Maes Hughes|Maes Hughes]], Mustang investigates the incident in secret despite the military closing the case after convicting [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Denny Brosh and Maria Ross|Maria Ross]]. Trusting in Ross's innocence, Mustang fakes Ross's death and engineer her escape from Amestris.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 9|chapter=Chapter 35|year=2006|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-0460-5}}{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 10|chapter=Chapter 40|year=2006|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-0461-2}} While breaking into a military laboratory, Mustang kills [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Lust|Lust]], an immortal creature known as a homunculus, who was investigating his actions and was going to kill subordinates.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 10|chapter=Chapter 39|year=2006|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-0461-2}} Recovering from his wounds, Mustang learns that the [[Führer]] [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#King Bradley|King Bradley]] is also a homunculus and tries to expose him to the top echelons of the military.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 12|chapter=Chapter 49|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-0839-9}} This move costs Mustang and deprives him of his subordinates - Bradley places Hawkeye under his command and authorizes the transfer of Mustang's remaining personnel to the far reaches of Amestris.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 14|chapter=Chapter 56|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-1379-9}} Mustang is later contacted by General [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Olivier Armstrong|Olivier Armstrong]], who is intending to join forces with various troops to attack Central City, the capital of Amestris. He then meets up with his subordinates, and the four attack Central's military while Bradley is gone.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 19|chapter=Chapter 74|year=2008|publisher=Square Enix|isbn=978-4-7575-2237-4}} Mustang later confronts the homunculus [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Envy|Envy]] after learning that he was Hughes' true murderer; fueled by rage, Mustang easily defeats Envy. As Mustang prepares to finish Envy off, he is convinced by Hawkeye, Edward, and Scar not to kill him and allow his own thirst for vengeance to consume him.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 23|chapter=Chapter 95|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-3630-9}} Later, the homunculi attack Mustang, forcing him to use alchemy to become the fifth human sacrifice needed for their leader.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 25|chapter=Chapter 101|year=2011|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-3924-9}} This results in Mustang losing his eyesight as part of the sacrifice, although he continues to fight with Hawkeye to help him direct his attacks.{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 25|chapter=Chapter 102|year=2011|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-3924-9}} However, after the final fight is over, a former comrade, [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Tim Marcoh|Tim Marcoh]], offers to use a Philosopher's Stone to restore Mustang's eyesight on the condition that he promises that he will be a part of a movement to restore Ishbal. Mustang accepts and is put in charge of the East region as [[brigadier general]].{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist, Volume 27|chapter=Chapter 108|year=2011|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-3984-3}} ===In the first anime=== During the first anime, Mustang remains at Eastern Headquarters for the early portions of the series until he is transferred back to Central after Hughes' death.{{cite episode|title=Words of Farewell|airdate=April 30, 2005|number=25|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} When pursuing the Elrics after the Stone's creation in Liore, Mustang learns that the Führer is a homunculus, and tries to expose him to the top brass of the military by revealing the truth about the Führer's [[secretary]], [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Sloth|Juliet Douglas]].{{cite episode|title=A Rotted Heart|airdate=February 4, 2006|number=45|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} Although Bradley intends for him to die in combat during the Northern Campaign, Mustang instead stays in Central, making his move to avenge Hughes. Mustang then moves on to the Führer's mansion and stages his fight.{{cite episode|title=Death|airdate=2006-03-18|number=50|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} Mustang is able to defeat Bradley when his son, Selim, unwittingly brings the skull of the man from which the Führer was created and weakens Bradley. As Mustang escapes the Führer's mansion, he is confronted by a maniacal [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Frank Archer|Frank Archer]], who shoots him. Hawkeye arrives in time to save Mustang and kills Archer.{{cite episode|title=Laws and Promises|airdate=2006-03-18|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Cartoon Network}} In ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa]]'', Mustang resigns from both alchemy and his rank to become an ordinary enlisted man in a remote outpost. However, when Central is under attack by armies and airships from a parallel universe, Mustang steps up and takes command, using his alchemy to defend Central. Mustang and his comrade [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Alex Louis Armstrong|Alex Louis Armstrong]] are able to find a hot-air balloon to reach the airships, where he is reunited with the Elric brothers, and helps them gain entry into the airship. At the end of the movie, Al says that Mustang and his team are now responsible for destroying the Amestris side of the Gate.{{cite video | people=Mizushima, Seiji (Director) | date=2005-07-23 | url=http://www.sonymusic.co.jp/Animation/hagaren/hagaren-movie/index.html | title=Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa | medium=Motion picture | location=Japan | publisher=Bones | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070318042714/http://www.sonymusic.co.jp/Animation/hagaren/hagaren-movie/index.html | archivedate=2007-03-18 | df= }} ===In other media=== Besides his appearances in the manga and the anime, Mustang also appears in most of the [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist episodes#OVAs|''Fullmetal Alchemist'' original video animations]], which are [[omake]] of the first anime and the film sequel.{{cite video |date = 2009 |title = Fullmetal Alchemist: Premium OVA Collection|type=[[DVD]] |publisher = Funimation}} In the fourth light novel of the series written by Makoto Inoue, ''Fullmetal Alchemist: Under the Faraway Sky'', Mustang, Hughes, and Armstrong find a village populated by children while they are on holidays.{{cite book|author=Inoue, Makoto|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: Under the Faraway Sky|chapter=Roy's Holidays|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-1397-3}} In the following title, Mustang appears investigating a case involving chimeras.{{cite book|author=Inoue, Makoto|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: The Ties That Bind|year=2007|publisher=Viz Media|isbn=978-1-4215-1431-4}} In video games of the series, Mustang commonly appears as a supporting character in the Elric brothers' investigation of the Philosopher's Stone.{{cite web|url=http://www.square-enix.co.jp/hagaren3/|publisher=[[Square Enix]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist 3: Kami o Tsugu Shōjo official website|accessdate=2008-03-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327102322/http://www.square-enix.co.jp/hagaren3/|archivedate=2008-03-27|df=}} He is also featured in several cards of the ''Fullmetal Alchemist Trading Card Game''.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000ARTBV2/|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Booster Box|accessdate=2008-03-31}} Mustang's character is featured in the second volume of the character CDs series from ''Fullmetal Alchemist''. The CD was published on December 15, 2004 under the name of ''Hagaren Song File - Roy Mustang''. The tracks were composed by Kazuya Nishioka and performed by [[Toru Okawa]], Mustang's Japanese voice actor in the first ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' anime.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000666WQE/|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|title=HAGAREN SONG FILE-ROY MUSTANG- Maxi (Soundtrack)|accessdate=August 1, 2009}} Additionally, Mustang is portrayed by [[Dean Fujioka]] in the live-action film based on the series.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/04/03-1/dean-fujioka-and-others-join-live-action-fullmetal-alchemist-film|title=Dean Fujioka and Others Join Live-Action "Fullmetal Alchemist" Film|publisher=Crunchyroll|accessdate=April 3, 2016|date=April 3, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406024335/http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/04/03-1/dean-fujioka-and-others-join-live-action-fullmetal-alchemist-film|archivedate=April 6, 2016|df=}} ==Creation and conception== Before ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' started publication, Arakawa had already thought that during the series, Mustang and his soldiers would fight against the antagonist [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Lust|Lust]]. She wanted that fight to be one of Mustang's most impressive scenes in the series, so she decided to give him calmer situations before writing such a scene. Having had only one important scene before his fight against Lust made readers of the series criticize Mustang's appearances; in order to change the readers' opinions about him before the outcome, Arakawa set up the sub-plot of how Maria Ross was accused of killing [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#Maes Hughes|Maes Hughes]] and Mustang would intervene there. When [[List of Fullmetal Alchemist characters#King Bradley|King Bradley]] was revealed to be an antagonist, Arakawa wanted to differentiate the two characters via their treatment of their subordinates, with Mustang being unwilling to sacrifice them, unlike Bradley. Arakawa had trouble depicting this, feeling it was an important part of the series, and was unsure whether the result was good.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=鋼の錬金術師 パーフェクトガイドブック 2| year=2005 | publisher=Square Enix|pages=168–172| isbn=978-4-7575-1426-3 }} When the first guidebook of the series was released, Arakawa was surprised by the large number of images featuring Mustang and supposed he was a character "that's easy to mess with."{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Profiles| year=2006 | publisher=Viz Media |pages=100–105| isbn=1-4215-0768-4 }} Regarding Mustang's popularity within fans, Arakawa stated that while some consider him good-looking, it is still above average and that he was not too tall.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=鋼の錬金術師 CHRONICLE| year=2011 | publisher=Square Enix|pages=| isbn=978-4-7575-3249-6 }} While checking sketches she made before the series, Arakawa commented that most featuring Mustang are comical, with few of them showing him with a serious expression.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Rough Sketch Gallery|trans-title=| year=2006 | publisher=Square Enix|page=25| isbn=978-4-7575-1695-3 }} After ending the series, Arakawa was asked by several fans if Mustang and Riza Hawkeye ever married; she replied that they could not marry as it would result in Hawkeye not being able to continue serving Mustang due to military regulations.{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=荒川弘イラスト集 FULLMETAL ALCHEMIST 3 | year=2011 | publisher=Square Enix|page=109| isbn=978-4-7575-3220-5}} In the first ''Fullmetal Alchemist'' anime series, Mustang was voiced by [[Toru Okawa]],{{cite episode|title=おかあさん......|airdate=October 18, 2003|credits=Director: Seiji Mizushima|series=Fullmetal Alchemist|network=Tokyo Broadcasting System}} while in the second anime, Okawa was replaced by [[Shin-ichiro Miki]].{{cite episode|title=鋼の錬金術師|airdate=April 5, 2009|credits=Director: Yasuhiro Irie|series=Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood|network=Tokyo Broadcasting System}} In the English dub of the first and second anime, Mustang was voiced by [[Travis Willingham]]. Willingham first auditioned for the part of Mustang after [[Justin Cook]] said he would be just right for the role. He also auditioned for Armstrong, which was cast to [[Christopher Sabat]]. Willingham also stated that during production, he and [[Vic Mignogna]] re-recorded several parts as he was not satisfied with the result.{{cite web|url=http://www.sequentialtart.com/archive/aug05/fullmetal.shtml|author=O'Connell, Margaret|title=Sequential Tart - The Fullmetal Interview Part 1|publisher=Sequentalart.com|date=2007-01-08|accessdate=2009-06-08}} ==Reception== [[File:Travis Willingham by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|[[Travis Willingham]], who provided the English voice of Mustang, received praise and the character was noted to have launched his voice acting career.]] During January from 2007, [[Oricon]] made a poll in which they asked Japanese fans which characters from any series they would most like to see in spin-off series. In the survey "Men's choices", Mustang ranked sixth.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-01-08/oricon-fans-want-l-char-aznable-spinoffs|title=Oricon: Fans Want L, Char Aznable Spinoffs|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=2007-01-08|accessdate=2009-06-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070402171927/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-01-08/oricon-fans-want-l-char-aznable-spinoffs|archivedate=2007-04-02|df=}} In the July 2009 issue of ''[[Newtype]]'', Mustang ranked sixth in the survey best anime male characters.{{cite journal|work=[[Newtype]], Issue 8|date=July 2009|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|title=NT Research}} In the August 2009 issue his rank changed to #8.{{cite journal|work=[[Newtype]], Issue 9|date=August 2009|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|title=NT Research}} In another ''Newtype'' poll from web|url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_2004.html|script-title=ja:第26回アニメグランプリ　2004年6月号|publisher=[[Animage]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=April 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716175939/http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_2004.html|archivedate=July 16, 2011|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_2005.html|script-title=ja:第26回アニメグランプリ　2005年6月号|publisher=[[Animage]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=April 11, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090627174422/http://animage.jp/old/gp/gp_2005.html|archivedate=June 27, 2009|df=}} His character has ranked second in all of the popularity polls from series developed by ''[[Gangan Comics#Monthly Shōnen Gangan|Monthly Shōnen Gangan]]'', each time being surpassed by [[Edward Elric]].{{cite book | last=Arakawa | first=Hiromu | title=Fullmetal Alchemist Profiles| year=2006 | publisher=Viz Media |page=5| isbn=1-4215-0768-4 }}{{cite book|author=Arakawa, Hiromu|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Character Guide|pages=2–3|year=2009|publisher=Square Enix|isbn=978-4-7575-2574-0}} Merchandising based on Mustang's likeness has also been released, including figurines, keychains and gloves for cosplaying.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000QUFKV8/|title=Fullmetal Alchemist Roy Mustang Anime Cosplay Gloves|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=August 1, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000UOD526/|title=Full Metal Alchemist Roy Mustang Clip-On Charm|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=August 1, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000G26SEY/|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: Roy Mustang Figure|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=August 1, 2009}} [[Shin-ichiro Miki]], Mustang's Japanese voice actor in ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood]]'', was the winner of the fourth [[Seiyu Awards]] in the category "Best Supporting Actor Awards" for his role as Mustang, as well as ''[[Mobile Suit Gundam 00]]''{{'}}s [[Lockon Stratos]].{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-03-06/4th-annual-seiyu-award-winners-announced|title=News: 4th Annual Seiyū Award Winners Announced|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=March 6, 2010|accessdate=April 5, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308032533/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-03-06/4th-annual-seiyu-award-winners-announced|archivedate=March 8, 2010|df=}} [[Nippon Telegraph and Telephone|NTT]] customers voted him as their eleventh favorite black-haired male anime character.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2014-05-05/japanese-fans-rank-their-favorite-black-haired-anime-characters|title=Japanese Fans Rank Their Favorite Black-Haired Anime Day |date=May 20, 2017 |accessdate=May 21, 2017 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170520190543/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/the-list/2017-05-20/.116359 |archivedate=May 20, 2017 |df= }} Publications of manga, anime, and other media have commented on Mustang's character in both the manga and anime. While reviewing the first volume of the manga, Manga Life found that Mustang's character was more mature in the manga than in the anime.{{Cite web |last= |first= |url=http://www.mangalife.com/reviews/FullMetalAlchemistv1II.htm |title=Full Metal Alchemist v1 [II] |work=Manga Life |date= |accessdate=2009-07-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219051700/http://www.mangalife.com/reviews/FullMetalAlchemistv1II.htm |archivedate=2006-02-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On the other hand, in the review from the first anime's last episodes, Lori Lancaster from Mania Entertainment enjoyed Mustang's relationship with Edward, comparing him to a "teasing and protective older brother".{{cite web| title=Fullmetal Alchemist Set 4| author=Lancanster, Lori| url=http://www.mania.com/fullmetal-alchemist-set-4_article_80078.html| publisher=Mania Entertainment| date=2008-07-18| accessdate=2009-07-07| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523173528/http://www.mania.com/fullmetal-alchemist-set-4_article_80078.html| archivedate=2009-05-23| df=}} Sakura Eries from the same site noted that Mustang "steals the show" in Volume 10 of the manga, praising his fighting skills during his battle against Lust and Gluttony. Additionally, when Maria Ross was revealed in the same volume to be alive and that she was not killed by Mustang, Eries remarked on his work as leader, taking back her negative comments regarding Mustang when she thought that Mustang really killed her.{{cite web| title=Fullmetal Alchemist Vol. #10| author=Eries, Sakura| url=http://www.mania.com/fullmetal-alchemist-vol-10_article_82820.html| publisher=Mania Entertainment| date=2007-07-27| accessdate=2009-07-07| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706073515/http://www.mania.com/fullmetal-alchemist-vol-10_article_82820.html| archivedate=2010-07-06| df=}} These sub-plots were also commented by [[IGN]]'s D. F. Smith, as they expanded Mustang's character much more than in the first anime series, where he had relatively smaller appearances.{{cite web|url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/111/1115485p1.html|title=Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood - Part Two DVD Review|date=August 26, 2010|author=Smith, D.F.|accessdate=September 11, 2011|publisher=[[IGN]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820010405/http://dvd.ign.com/articles/111/1115485p1.html|archivedate=August 20, 2011|df=}} Lydia Hojnacki from PopCultureShock noted Mustang's character as one of the reasons she likes the series, noting his personality and relation with the Elric brothers.{{cite web| title=Three Reasons Why I Love Fullmetal Alchemist| author=Hojnacki, Lydia| url=http://www.popcultureshock.com/manga/index.php/manga-recon/three-reasons-why-i-love-full-metal-alchemist/| publisher=PopCultureShock| date=2008-12-31| accessdate=2009-07-15| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406004513/http://www.popcultureshock.com/manga/index.php/manga-recon/three-reasons-why-i-love-full-metal-alchemist/| archivedate=2009-04-06| df=}} When he watched ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist the Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa]]'', [[Anime News Network]] writer Theron Martin mentioned that when Mustang "makes his dramatic return in a cheer-out-loud moment", he remarked the audience "went wild at that point".{{cite web| title=Fullmetal Alchemist: The Movie - Conqueror of Shamballa DVD| author=Martin, Theron| url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/fullmetal-alchemist-the-movie-conquer| publisher=[[Anime News Network]]| date=2006-09-23| accessdate=2009-07-07| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722190301/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/fullmetal-alchemist-the-movie-conquer| archivedate=2009-07-22| df=}} In IGN's review of the same film, Jeremy Mullin commented that he wanted to see Mustang's counterpart from Germany, as several characters from the series had their counterparts, but then said "it does make it fun imagining what" he would be.{{cite web|url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/737/737692p1.html|title=IGN: Fullmetal Alchemist The Movie: Conqueror of Shamballa review (page 1)|date=October 6, 2006|author=Mullin, Jeremy|accessdate=July 3, 2009|publisher=[[IGN]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090726155100/http://dvd.ign.com/articles/737/737692p1.html|archivedate=July 26, 2009|df=}} David Smith from the same site cited his role and ambitions in the first anime series in the feature "Ten Things I Learned From Fullmetal Alchemist", which had comments on his flaws.{{cite web|url=http://anime.ign.com/articles/860/860537p2.html|title=Ten Things I Learned From Fullmetal Alchemist|date=March 18, 2008|author=Smith, David|accessdate=May 17, 2010|publisher=[[IGN]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322000422/http://anime.ign.com/articles/860/860537p2.html|archivedate=March 22, 2008|df=}} In an analysis of the series, Fetch Amber, a writer from [[Bowling Green State University]], noted that while Mustang is the one that encounters Lust in the series and kills her, the fight does not mean there was a poor characterization of the homunculus' sexualization based on how different both Mustang and Lust are: while Mustang is always in one area, Lust takes a more active role in the story to the point of seeing the former as a less masculine person. While noting that Mustang is a brave man based on his actions and powers, Amber noted that there are multiple parts of the story where Mustang loses control of himself, such as when he tries to avenge the wound Jean Havok suffered in combat. A similar scene is noted in his fight against Envy where the Colonel incinerates Envy multiple times before Envy ends up killing himself, leading Amber to question whether Arakawa was reaffirming the superiority between a male and a female character based on the fact that while Envy has no gender, he is still referred as a male.{{cite journal |last=Amber |first=Fetch |year=2014 |title=More than Alchemic Reactions: Playing with Gender Norms in Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood |work= |publisher=Bowling Green State University |publication-place= |page= |url=https://etd.ohiolink.edu/pg_10?0::NO:10:P10_ACCESSION_NUM:bgsu1395617137 |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |isbn= |issn= |oclc= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710001954/https://etd.ohiolink.edu/pg_10?0::NO:10:P10_ACCESSION_NUM:bgsu1395617137 |archivedate=July 10, 2018 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Fullmetal Alchemist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mustang, Roy}} [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 2001]] [[Category:Fictional alchemists]] [[Category:Fictional attempted suicides]] [[Category:Fictional blind characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters with fire or heat abilities]] [[Category:Fictional characters with elemental transmutation abilities]] [[Category:Fictional colonels]] [[Category:Fictional commanders]] [[Category:Fictional corporals]] [[Category:Fictional generals]] [[Category:Fictional lieutenant colonels]] [[Category:Fictional majors]] [[Category:Fictional soldiers]] [[Category:Fullmetal Alchemist characters]] [[Category:Male characters in anime and manga]]

'''Sir Lionel''' is the younger son of King [[Bors]] of Gaunnes (or [[Gaul]]) and [[Evaine]] and brother of [[Bors the Younger]] in [[Arthurian legend]] since the [[Launcelot-Grail]] cycle. He is a [[double cousin]] of [[Launcelot]] and cousin of Launcelot's younger half-brother [[Ector de Maris]] (not to be confused with the older Sir Ector, who was [[King Arthur]]'s foster-father).
==Arthurian legend== When their father dies in battle against King [[Claudas]], Lionel and [[Sir Bors|Bors]] are rescued by the [[Lady of the Lake]] and raised in her underwater kingdom alongside her foster-son [[Lancelot]]. Like all his family, Lionel becomes a [[Knight of the Round Table]].
[[Image:Bors and Lionel.jpg|thumb|Bors chooses to save a maiden rather than his brother Lionel]]
While traveling with Lancelot as a young man, Lionel is captured by the rogue knight Turquine, who whips him with [[briar (thicket)|briars]] and throws him in the dungeon. The scenario repeats itself later while he is on the [[Holy Grail|Quest for the Holy Grail]], where he proves very unworthy of the blessed object by trying to kill his brother for not rescuing him. Bors had seen Lionel getting beaten and led away, but had to make a decision to save either him or a young girl being dragged in the opposite direction. He saves the girl, and fears Lionel dead. But Lionel escapes, and attacks Bors the next time they meet. Bors proves himself worthy of the Grail when he refuses to fight back, and Lionel kills a religious hermit and [[Calogrenant|Sir Calogrenant]], a fellow Knight of the [[Round Table]], when they try to protect Bors from his wrath. Before Lionel can strike his brother, however, God intervenes and immobilizes him.
Lionel and the rest of his family follow Lancelot into exile when the affair with Queen [[Guinevere]] is exposed. Lionel participates in the battles against [[King Arthur]] and becomes King of Gaunnes. After the [[Battle of Camlann]], Lancelot's family returns to Britain to defeat the remainder of [[Mordred]]'s forces. Lionel is slain by Mordred's son Melehan; Bors avenges his death.
Sir Lionel is the subject of the late-medieval [[folk song|folk ballad]] "Sir Lionel", recorded as [[Child Ballads|Child Ballad]] 18 and [[Roud Folk Song Index|Roud]] #29, in which he slays a giant [[wild boar]].<ref>[[Francis James Child]], ''English and Scottish Popular Ballads'', [http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/eng/child/ch018.htm "Sir Lionel"]</ref> This song has much in common with a medieval tale about a knight who slays a terrifyingly fiendish boar in [[Sidon]], in the fourteenth century [[Romance (heroic literature)|romance]] of ''[[Sir Eglamour of Artois]]''.<ref>Francis James Child, The English and Scottish Popular Ballads, v 1, p 209, Dover Publications, New York 1965</ref> The terrible swine is a frequent foe in romantic tales, for instance the beast [[Twrch Trwyth]] in ''[[Culhwch and Olwen]]''.<ref>Francis James Child, The English and Scottish Popular Ballads, v 1, p 209-10, Dover Publications, New York 1965</ref> The song was recorded in [[Appalachia]] as late as the early 20th century. Popular variants include "Old Bangum" and "Wild Hog".
==Modern works== *In the musical ''[[Camelot (musical)|Camelot]]'', Lionel is the knight brought back to life by Launcelot after he accidentally kills him in a joust. *Lionel appears in the 1998 animated film ''[[Quest for Camelot]]'' as the father of the protagonist, Kayley, who wished to follow her father's footsteps. During the beginning of the film, Lionel is killed by the main antagonist, Sir Ruber, who intends to claim the throne of Camelot for himself, while trying to kill King Arthur, whom Lionel defended before he died.

[[File:Righteous Syncletica of Alexandria (Menologion of Basil II).jpg|thumb|300px|right|Painting depicting Syncletica of Alexandria, from the [[Menologion of Basil II]] (c. 1000 AD)]] '''Amma Syncletica of Alexandria''', a [[Christian]] [[saint]] and [[Desert Mother]] of the 4th century, was of a wealthy background and is reputed to have been very beautiful. From childhood, however, Syncletica was drawn to [[Trinity|God]] and the desire to dedicate her life to him.
From the time she gained responsibility for her family's affairs, after the death of her parents, she gave all that had been left her to the poor. With her younger sister Syncletica abandoned the life of the city and chose to reside in a [[crypt]] adopting the life of a [[hermit]]. Her holy life soon gained the attention of locals and gradually many women came to live as her [[Disciple (Christianity)|disciples]] in [[Christ]].
St. Syncletica is regarded as a "Desert Mother" and her sayings are recorded with those of the [[Desert Fathers]]. She is believed to have died in her eightieth year, around 350 AD.
Amma Syncletica is commemorated 5 January in the [[Orthodox Church]], [[Eastern Catholic Churches]], and the [[Roman Catholic Church]].

Bleszynski began her career in the soap opera ''Anakku Terlahir Kembali'' in [[RCTI]] in 1996. ==Early life== Bleszynski's father is Zbigniew Bleszynski, who is of [[Poles|Polish]] descent, and her mother is Farida Gasik, of [[Sundanese people|Sunda]] descent. She completed her education in Indonesia and subsequently in [[Perth]], [[Australia]]. She has been interested in acting most of her life. She took extracurricular drama classes in junior high school and continued acting in high school. She obtained a bachelor's degree of Business Management in [[St Brigid's College|St Brigid's College Australia]], but continued to be interested in acting, so she joined the Theatre Institute. ==Career== On return to Indonesia, Bleszynski was noticed in a record store by Jay Subiyakto, who suggested she should become a model. She got a contract to advertise Lux, a beauty soap. Bleszynski began acting in soap operas with her appearance in ''Anakku Terlahir Kembali'' (1996) and its sequel, where she appeared with teen idol [[Desy Ratnasari]]. Returning to acting after the birth of her child in 2000, she appeared in ''Doa Membawa Berkah'' (2000), directed by Ahmad Yusuf. She converted to [[Islam]], and began appearing in religious soap operas. She played in ''Wah Cantiknya !!!'' (2001) and ''Hikmah'' (2004), for which she won "Favorite Actress" at 2004 and 2005 [[Panasonic Awards]]. Bleszynski's first appearance in film was in ''Issue'' (2004), followed by ''Big Day'' (2006). In 2008, Bleszynski played the action figure Rrama in ''[[Cicakman 2: Planet Hitam]]'' and in 2009 worked in the slasher film ''Air Terjun Pengantin''. For this role, she tanned her skin and trained to create an athletic body for the martial arts scenes in her role as Tiara. Other movies she has appeared in include ''Opera SMU'' (2002), ''Ikhlas'' (2003), ''Issue'' (2004), ''Putri Cantik'' (2004), ''Goal'' (2005), and ''Cinta Itu Nggak Buta'' (2007). She appeared in the television film ''Dibalik Jendela Astrid'' in 2002). With the Theater Institute, she was cast as Calpurnia, wife of Julius Caesar in ''Julius Caesar'' (1997). ==Personal life== Bleszynski converted to [[Islam]] in 1995. She married Teuku Rafly Pasha in 1997, and they have one son. They divorced in 2007. She married [[Mike Lewis (model)]] in 2010, and they have one son of this [[interfaith marriage]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arenaunik.com/2010/09/tamara-dan-mike-lewis-menikah-beda.html|title=Tamara dan Mike Lewis menikah beda agama|date=2 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223235600/http://www.arenaunik.com/2010/09/tamara-dan-mike-lewis-menikah-beda.html|archivedate=23 December 2015|df=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.detikhot.com/read/2010/12/22/161554/1530900/230/tamara-blezynski-melahirkan-bayi-laki-laki?h991103207|title=Tamara Blezynski Melahirkan Bayi Laki-Laki|publisher=detik.hot.com|date=22 December 2010}} They divorced in 2012.{{cite web |url=http://jabar.tribunnews.com/2012/05/28/tamara-blezsynski-dan-mike-lewis-resmi-bercerai |title=Tamara Blezsynski dan Mike Lewis Resmi Bercerai|publisher=jabar.tribunnews.com |date=26 May 2012}} Bleszynski continues to work as an actor, model, and brand ambassador, and is part owner in a restaurant, Resto Negev, where she also acted as a chef. ==Discography== ===Single=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox film | name = Banger Sisters | image = Banger_sisters.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Bob Dolman]] | producer = {{ubl|Elizabeth Cantillon|[[Mark Johnson (producer)|Mark Johnson]]}} | writer = Bob Dolman | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Goldie Hawn]] * [[Susan Sarandon]] * [[Geoffrey Rush]] }} | music = [[Trevor Rabin]] | cinematography = [[Karl Walter Lindenlaub]] | editing = Aram Nigoghossian | distributor = [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2002|9|8|[[Deauville American Film Festival|Deauville]]|2002|9|20|United States}} | runtime = 98 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $10 million | gross = $38.1 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=bangersisters.htm|title=The Banger Sisters (2002) - Box Office Mojo|website=www.boxofficemojo.com}} }} '''''The Banger Sisters''''' is a 2002 American [[comedy film]] written and directed by [[Bob Dolman]], and produced by [[Fox Searchlight Pictures]]. The film stars [[Goldie Hawn]] and [[Susan Sarandon]] as two middle-aged women who used to be friends and [[groupie]]s when they were young. It was released on September 20, 2002. The film was Hawn's last acting role until the release of ''[[Snatched (2017 film)|Snatched]]'' in 2017, fourteen and a half years after the release of ''The Banger Sisters''. ==Plot== When Suzette (Hawn) is fired from her job as bartender at the [[Whisky A Go-Go]] in [[Los Angeles]], she decides, on the spur of the moment, to travel all the way to [[Phoenix, Arizona]] to see her old friend Vinnie (Sarandon). Stranded at a service station without any money to buy some gasoline, she picks up Harry Plummer (Rush), a neurotic, middle-aged author who is on his way to Phoenix to once and for all come to grips with the negative influence his father has had over his life. On arriving in Phoenix, Suzette has a chance to meet with Vinnie's 17-year-old daughter Hannah ([[Erika Christensen]]) who, after some [[recreational drug use]], starts throwing up in Harry's hotel room. When she drives her back to her parents' elegant suburban home Suzette at first cannot believe what she sees: Vinnie, who now calls herself Lavinia Kingsley, leads the more [[conservative]] life of the perfect wife and mother—a life which at one point prompts one of her daughters to ask Suzette, "Did she ''ever'' do ''anything'' wrong?" Raymond, Vinnie's lawyer husband and an aspiring politician, has no idea about his wife's past either. However, Suzette's sudden appearance brings back all those memories for Lavinia. Down in the basement she retrieves some of the memorabilia of their previous life as groupies, including a collection of [[Instant film|Polaroids]] of the penises of numerous "musicians and a few [[roadie]]s". She cuts her hair and throws off her expensive but boring clothes and, just for one night, relives the old days by going dancing with Suzette. In the end, both her husband and her two daughters have understood that Lavinia is only human after all. In her graduation speech, Hannah speaks out against anything that is "fake" and urges her schoolmates, teachers and the parents present to "do it true". On the following day, Suzette returns to Los Angeles together with Harry, who has come to consider her his muse. ==Cast== * [[Goldie Hawn]] as Suzette * [[Susan Sarandon]] as Lavinia "Vinnie" Kingsley * [[Geoffrey Rush]] as Harry Plummer * [[Erika Christensen]] as Hannah Kingsley * [[Robin Thomas]] as Raymond Kingsley * [[Eva Amurri]] as Ginger Kingsley * [[Matthew Carey]] as Jules * Andre Ware as Jake the Bartender * Adam Tomei as Club Owner * Sal Lopez as Pump Attendant * [[Kohl Sudduth]] as Hotel Clerk * [[Tinsley Grimes]] as Prom Girl * Larry Krask as Man in Bar * Marlayna Garrett as Young Groupie * [[Buckcherry]] as Themselves == Reception == The film was released on September 20, 2002. It opened at #2, in 2,738 theaters, grossing $10,037,846 during its opening weekend. It went on to gross $30,307,416 domestically and $7,760,937 from overseas markets, for a worldwide total of $38,068,353. Reviews of the movie were mixed. The film holds a 47% rating at [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with the consensus stating: "Hawn and Sarandon are terrific together, but the hoary plot is predictable and contrived."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/banger_sisters/|title=The Banger Sisters|publisher=}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" | Award ! scope="col" | Category ! scope="col" | Recipient ! scope="col" | Result |- | [[60th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]] | [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Comedy or Musical|Best Actress - Motion Picture Comedy or Musical]] | [[Goldie Hawn]] | {{nom}}

{{Infobox person | name = William Alexander Morgan | image = File:William Alexander Morgan.jpg| alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1928|4|19}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland, Ohio]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1961|03|11|1928|4|19}} | death_place = Havana, Cuba | burial_place = Cuba | nationality = US | citizenship = American (revoked 1959) | allegiance = {{flagu|United States|1960}} (until 1959) | branch = {{flag|United States Army}} | serviceyears = 1945-1948 | other_names = | occupation = Revolutionary | years_active = 1957–1961 | known_for = Commander of the Second National Front of the Escambray | notable_works = }}
'''William Alexander Morgan''' (April 19, 1928 – March 11, 1961) was a United States citizen who fought in the [[Cuban Revolution]], leading a band of rebels that drove the Cuban army from key positions in the central mountains as part of [[Second National Front of Escambray]], thereby helping to pave the way for Fidel Castro's forces to secure victory. Morgan was one of about two dozen U.S. citizens to fight in the revolution and one of only three foreign nationals to hold the rank of [[Commandant#Latin America|comandante]] in the rebel forces.<ref>The others were [[Che Guevara]], an Argentine citizen, and [[Eloy Gutiérrez Menoyo]], a Spanish citizen.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}}</ref> He turned against Castro after the revolution when Castro began to show Communist leanings, and was one of the leaders of the CIA supplied [[Escambray rebellion]].
==Life before Cuba== Morgan was born in [[Cleveland]], Ohio, to Alexander Morgan and [[German-American]] Loretta Morgan (née Ruderth).<ref name=grann /> Raised in an affluent [[Toledo, OH|Toledo]] neighborhood, he dropped out of high school and was often in trouble with the law.<ref name=sallah>Micheal Sallah, "The Yankee Comandante," ''The Toledo Blade", March 3-4-5, 2002</ref> Morgan joined the [[United States Army]] after [[World War II]] and married Darlene Edgerton in 1946. The marriage was annulled after a year and a half. He was stationed with Company B, 35th Infantry, in Japan, where he fathered a son with a German-Japanese hostess named Setsuko Takeda. He went [[AWOL]], was arrested, and escaped from custody by overpowering a guard. Recaptured, he was [[court-martialed]] in 1948, received a [[dishonorable discharge]], and spent over two years in a federal prison.<ref name=grann >{{cite news|last1=Grann|first1=David|title=The Yankee Comandante|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/05/28/the-yankee-comandante?currentPage=all|accessdate=23 July 2014|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=28 May 2012}}</ref>
He is said to have been skilled with firearms and was rumored to have been a [[Central Intelligence Agency]] operative, though there are no public records or witness interviews to support the claim.<ref name=sallah /> After his discharge from the Army, Morgan apparently also worked for a local crime syndicate.
On May 11, 1954, Morgan married Ellen Theresa May Bethel, a [[Snake charming|snake charmer]], in Miami. They had two children, Anne Marie (1955) and William A. Morgan Jr. (1957).<ref name=grann /><ref name=plot />
==Cuban Revolution== [[File:CheLaCoubreMarch.jpg|thumb|left|300px|From left to right: [[Fidel Castro]], [[Osvaldo Dorticós Torrado]], [[Che Guevara]], [[Augusto Martínez Sánchez]], [[Antonio Núñez Jiménez]], '''William Alexander Morgan''''and [[Eloy Gutiérrez Menoyo]].]] Opposed to the dictatorship of [[Fulgencio Batista]], Morgan abandoned his wife and children and went to Cuba in 1957, joining a guerrilla force of the Second National Front of the Escambray (Segundo Frente Nacional de Escambray or SFNE)<ref name=grann /> that operated against [[Batista]]'s soldiers in the [[Escambray Mountains]] in central Cuba.<ref name=sallah />
After distinguishing himself in a series of battles, he was promoted to the rank of [[comandante]], leading his own column. In 1958, he wrote a statement that appeared in the ''[[New York Times]]'' to explain his participation in Castro's revolution, "Why I Am Here". It said in part:<ref name=plot /> {{quote|I am here because I believe that the most important thing for free men to do is to protect the freedom of others. I am here so that my son, when he is grown, will not have to fight or die in a land not his own, because one man or group of men try to take his liberty from him. I am here because I believe that free men should take up arms and stand together and fight and destroy the groups and forces that want to take the rights of people away.}}
In December 1958, [[Che Guevara]] joined forces with Morgan's group and the ''[[Directorio Revolucionario Estudantil]]'' guerrillas of the Escambray mountains. Together they captured the city of [[Santa Clara, Cuba|Santa Clara]] on December 31. Twelve hours later, Batista fled Cuba. Morgan and his men occupied the city of [[Cienfuegos]] on January 1–2, 1959.<ref>Miguel A. Faria Jr., ''Cuba in Revolution—Escape from a Lost Paradise'' (2002), 69</ref>
In January 1959, he told a reporter that "all I'm interested in is settling down to a nice peaceful existence" but worried how U.S. authorities would respond to his military activities in Cuba. In March 1959, officials of the U.S. embassy in Havana warned Americans that participation in foreign military service could jeopardize their citizenship.<ref name=plot />
In August 1959, Morgan gained international attention when he helped smash a coup attempt orchestrated by [[Dominican Republic]] strongman [[Rafael Trujillo]] and others by pretending to lead the takeover while quietly divulging the plot to Fidel Castro in order to help the fledgling government.<ref name=plot>''New York Times'': [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1959/08/15/80598611.pdf "A Fighter with Castro," August 15, 1959], accessed June 25, 2012</ref><ref>''New York Times'': [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1959/08/16/88809825.pdf "Trouble for Castro," August 16, 1959], accessed June 25, 2012</ref>
In September 1959, the U.S. State Department revoked his citizenship, a move that was prompted by members of Congress who had supported Trujillo. Morgan promised to contest the action.<ref>''New York Times'': [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1959/09/06/89235171.pdf "Castro's U.S. Aides Out," September 6, 1959], accessed June 25, 2012</ref>
==Post-revolution activities and execution== Morgan married a Cuban, Olga María Rodríguez Farinas, also a [[revolutionary]], they had two daughters.<ref name=sallah /> In August 1959, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] and American authorities revoked Morgan's U.S. citizenship.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Americano: Fighting with Castro for Cuba's Freedom|last=Shetterly|first=Aran|publisher=Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill|year=2007|isbn=9781565124585|location=Chapel Hill, N.C.|pages=209-254}}</ref> On September 24, 1959, Morgan renounced his U.S. citizenship publicly on a Havana radio station.<ref name=":0" /> After the revolution, Morgan developed a business of frog farming; with the legs being sold to restaurants, the skin for fashion accessories, and what remained for cattle feed. During this venture, Morgan would employ around 600 workers and ship an average of 50,000 pounds of frozen frog legs to the U.S. every month.<ref name=":0" />
On March 6, 1960, the French freighter [[La Coubre explosion|La Coubre]] exploded in [[Havana Harbor]] killing around 100 people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cuban-exile.com/doc_151-175/doc0166.html|title=La Coubre: Explodes in Havana 1960|last=|first=|date=|website=Cuban Information Archives|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 7, 2017}}</ref> An American named Jack Lee Evans, who was in Cuba at the time of the explosion with Morgan, left for Miami a few days after the incident. While in Miami, he gave an interview with the ''[[Miami Herald]]'' suggesting that Morgan had been involved with the sabotaging of the ship, which Morgan adamantly denied. A memorial for the explosion was held a few days later. Morgan would be pictured arm and arm walking through the streets of Havana during this memorial with prominent Cuban leaders including Castro and Che.<ref name=":0" />
Throughout the struggle against Batista, Morgan was vocal about Castro's supposed [[anti-communist]] beliefs. When asked during interviews about Castro's political beliefs and where the new Cuban government was leaning, he remained firm in his belief that Castro was not a communist and that Cuba would become a capitalist [[parliamentary democracy]].
As Castro began to reveal his socialist leanings, Morgan became disenchanted with the revolutionary government, as did other members of the SFNE, who wanted Cuba to restore elections. In the middle of June 1960, Morgan and a select few former Escambray leaders met to discuss Castro's turn towards socialism and protecting the Revolution.<ref name=":0" /> As the arrests of Morgan's former rebel comrades for counterrevolutionary activities started to increase, Morgan organized weapons to be smuggled to the counterrevolutionaries in the Escambray.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/05/28/the-yankee-comandante|title=The Yankee Comandante|last=Grann|first=David|date=May 28, 2012|website=The New Yorker|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 7, 2017}}</ref> ==Arrest and Execution== [[File:William Alexander Morgan in prison, Havana, Cuba. 1961.jpg|thumb|300px|left|William Alexander Morgan in prison, Havana, Cuba. 1961]] On October 16, 1960, Castro ordered Morgan's arrest due to counterrevolutionary activities. Three days later, Morgan was arrested while attending a meeting for the National Institute for Agrarian Reform, to which he had been summoned. Morgan was formally charged with plotting to join and lead the [[counter-revolutionaries]] who were active in the Escambray Mountains.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecubanhistory.com/2012/05/william-morgan-a-rebel-americano-in-cuba/|title=The American Comandante in the Cuban Revolutionary Forces: William Morgan|last=Varona|first=Arnoldo|date=May 16, 2012|website=The Cuban History|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 7, 2017}}</ref> On March 11, 1961, shortly after a military trial at La Cabana prison, Morgan, then 32 years old, was shot by firing squad with Fidel and Raul Castro in attendance.<ref name=grann /><ref name=":2" /> One month later, 1,500 [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] trained counterrevolutionaries would unsuccessfully invade Cuba at the [[Bay of Pigs Invasion|Bay of Pigs]] resulting in Castro officially declaring the Revolution a Socialist endeavor.<ref name=":1" />
His wife was tried with him ''[[trial in absentia|in absentia]]''. She was found guilty of co-conspiracy and sentenced to 30 years in prison.<ref name=sallah /> She was released after 10 years. She left for the United States in 1980 during the [[Mariel boatlift]]. In a series of interviews with ''[[The Toledo Blade]]'' in 2002, she admitted that she and her husband had begun running guns to anti-Castro [[guerrilla]]s because he was opposed to Castro's pro-[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] leanings. She also said she wanted Morgan's U.S. citizenship restored and his remains returned to the United States for reburial.<ref name=sallah /> The newspaper stories prompted two Democratic members of the [[United States House of Representatives]], [[Charles Rangel]] and [[Marcy Kaptur]], to travel to Cuba in April 2002 to meet Fidel Castro and ask him to return Morgan's body, and Castro agreed.<ref name=sallah />
In April 2007, nearly 50 years after the government stripped him of his rights in 1959 for serving in a foreign country's military, the [[US State Department]] declared that Morgan's [[US citizenship]] was effectively restored.<ref>Amy Driscoll, "U.S. reclaims citizen who led Cuban rebel fighters," ''Miami Herald'', April 13, 2007</ref>
== Morgan in pop culture == Morgan's story remained largely out of the American eye until the 21st century when articles, documentaries, and films introduced his story. In 2012, [[George Clooney]] planned to buy the rights and direct a film based on [[David Grann]]'s 2012 ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' article on Morgan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinemablend.com/new/George-Clooney-Direct-Biopic-Yankee-Comandante-31300.html|title=George Clooney to Direct Biopic the Yankee Comandante|last=Puchko|first=Kristy|date=November 2012|website=Cinema Blend|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 7, 2017}}</ref> Pulitzer prize-winning reporters [[Michael Sallah]] and [[Mitch Weiss]] authored the book, "The Yankee Comandante: The Untold Story of Courage, Passion and One American's Fight to Liberate Cuba."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-7627-9287-0|title=The Yankee Comandante: The Untold Story of Courage, Passion, and One American's Fight to Liberate Cuba |access-date=2018-10-20}}</ref> Morgan was featured in 2015 on the [[PBS]] documentary series ''[[American Experience]]'' with the episode titled American Comandante.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/films/comandante/|title=American Comandante|last=|first=|date=November 17, 2015|website=PBS|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 7, 2017}}</ref>
